posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked:
Hi everybody,

I have been using Signal for 4 years, but only lately been trying to push it to friends and colleagues. This led me to explore better the opportunities of the app e.g. stories, to promote them. I have then been using all of the features of the app‚Ä¶ except one.

There it is, in the middle of my menu, the ‚ÄúPayments‚Äù button, which very nicely brings me into an interface to buy and use a dead cryptocurrency! This is the only feature we don‚Äôt really talk about.

The coin itself looks very dead, down 71% in the last year and with a very low trade activity.

https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/mobilecoin

I know this topic has been very controversial and debated, however it might be time for an update and to re-evaluate the matter. I would like to ask the Signal Community few simple questions:

  1. Do you, or somebody you know actively use the Mobilecoin integration feature? Do we have some statistics, or estimate on which share of the Signal audience actually needs and want this?
  2. If the usage of the feature is very low, why keep it in the app? Why not create a separated app, so that people like me and my colleagues - and most people in the world - who don‚Äôt want nothing to do with cryptocurrencies don‚Äôt need to have this dead coin button in their app ( which I wish was the preference for messaging)?

I think that, in order to promote it to professionals and students (me myself am a researcher), this app would need to cut this tie to cryptocurrency, which looks very weird and shady - because yes, cryptocurrencies are still very shady in the eyes of most people, especially in Europe.

I wish to hear your thoughts on this matter!

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: MobileCoin doesn‚Äôt exist anymore. They rebranded some time ago. I don‚Äôt know why the wallet is still present nor if it‚Äôs still being worked on. The last commit I remember seeing for it was over a year ago.

posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked: Have the developers made any statement on this? Because I could not find anything recent. @Avitus

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Not that I‚Äôm aware of. It‚Äôs unlikely there will ever be a statement.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: I beisbol one of the C-level guys for mobile coin was killed some time ago also.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: honestly dead or not i‚Äôm pretty sure the intention was to develop the wallet and then forget about it. other than what are basically dependency updates the last real change i can find is from almost three years ago. i think this feature is considered ‚Äúdone‚Äù, so there‚Äôs not really anything to add, take or change, so i doubt anyone in Signal is really interested in mobilecoin anymore.

link_counts.title: Add in-chat payment activation requests. ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Android@77beeda ¬∑ GitHub

posts.cooked: It is leading to some people coming up with theories about Signal not being trustworthy because of ties to this coin and not wanting to use it. If it‚Äôs dead removing the integration would at least take away ammunition for spreading FUD about it.

posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked:
Exactly. I think an application free of cryptocurrency would be much easier to promote to my friends and family.

For the vast majority of people, cryptocurrencies are suspicious.

posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked:
But then is it worth it to follow the dependency updates and mantain the code to interface to an abandoned coin?

Does Signal really really want to keep this coin in my app?

I imagine it‚Äôs a lot harder to remove something than keep it up, if the only necessary updates are dependencies, removing it would mean having to make sure nothing else touches the code, and generally more work than probably needed considering nobody is using it anyway

posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked:
Search for ‚Äúmobilecoin‚Äù yelds

85 results on Signal-Android : Code search results ¬∑ GitHub

2 results on Signal-Desktop : Code search results ¬∑ GitHub

65 results on Signal-iOS : Code search results ¬∑ GitHub

5 results on Signal-Server: Code search results ¬∑ GitHub

4 results on libsignal : Code search results ¬∑ GitHub

You can appreciate how most of the code is in a ‚ÄúPayments‚Äù package. So I don‚Äôt think it is a crucial functional element. I might be mistaken, and you could show me that Mobilecoin is integrated more tightly e.g. in crucial components , but I think that would be more worrisome.

At this point, why not remove this code or move it to another app?

1. i don‚Äôt use mobilecoin, or any other crypto currency.
  2. i think mobilecoin integration should be removed.

mobilecoin basically failed, and it had some design issues, but i don‚Äôt go into details. because mobilecoin is dead, it is more shady for signal messenger.

generally speaking, crypto currencies should be separate apps even if communication app uses crypto technology for delivering messages. however, signal does not use any crypto technology for message delivery.

signal-cli still has api for currency transfer. so removing crypto options need some design changes as well. i still think it is relatively easy.

david.graziani:

Hi everybody,

‚Ä¶

  1. Do you, or somebody you know actively use the Mobilecoin integration feature? Do we have some statistics, or estimate on which share of the Signal audience actually needs and want this?
  2. If the usage of the feature is very low, why keep it in the app? Why not create a separated app, so that people like me and my colleagues - and most people in the world - who don‚Äôt want nothing to do with cryptocurrencies don‚Äôt need to have this dead coin button in their app ( which I wish was the preference for messaging)?

I think that, in order to promote it to professionals and students (me myself am a researcher), this app would need to cut this tie to cryptocurrency, which looks very weird and shady - because yes, cryptocurrencies are still very shady in the eyes of most people, especially in Europe.

I wish to hear your thoughts on this matter!
Talking about it or removing it will likely draw attention to it, what matters is that they don‚Äôt put anymore development effort into it.

posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt understand your point. I think having the wallet in the setting menu is drawing attention to it.

And the feature is still being developed (of course not very frequently, but still): History for app/src/main/java/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/payments - signalapp/Signal-Android ¬∑ GitHub

I don‚Äôt think it would be more work to remove the thing. The coin is dead and it‚Äôs time to remove it from Signal in my opinion.

posts.name: (he/him)
posts.cooked: perhaps there‚Äôs some contract about the partnership that we‚Äôre not aware of? e.g. Signal being required to keep the integration in the app for a specific amount of time.

Honestly I imagine they‚Äôre just focused more on other things like backups, and working on/removing something else doesn‚Äôt make sense if basically nobody cares about it in the first place (I can‚Äôt imagine many people ever actually used it in the first place)

posts.name: Davide
posts.cooked:
I think there are three cases:

A. The wallet code is entangled in crucial components for the functionality of Signal, which would be very worrisome.

B. The wallet code doesnt affect crucial components:

B1. They made it so it is hard to isolate and extract the feature, which would be bad design

B2. They can pretty easily delete the feature so the ‚Äúfocus‚Äù argument would not apply.

Like honestly, can a developer, or somebody familiar with the source code explain this? I really hope its the B2 case!
But I do understand the line of thinking that this will generate headlines and make people worry about it having been part of Signal, while they would never have noticed otherwise.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i think this is the main point. do we really want devs to spend time on removing a feature?
in Hebrew we have a phrase ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt eat and doesn‚Äôt drink‚Äù, meaning it‚Äôs harmless. now i am on record saying that MobileCoin may pose a risk to Signal, but this risk didn‚Äôt seem to materialise these past 3 years. so honestly, i just think touching the code isn‚Äôt worth the time. maybe that also includes updating dependencies 4-5 times a year, though i‚Äôm not sure what the implications of that would be.
but in my opinion it‚Äôs clear that with the coin being dead, it‚Äôs got no teeth to hurt anyone, so it‚Äôs not worth the time removing.
